name: Least List Lost Last
intro: Since there's a pair(x, y) operation in combinatory logic, one can already construct linked lists:
Such approach is very straightforward but requires explicit recursion for almost all operations.
Much like Church numerals, lists can be encoded as parametric higher order functions:
[a, b, c] f x = f a (f b (f c x)).
So a list in this notation is indistinguishable from its fold operation
We won't (yet) extend the notation with the [ and ];
you can find such syntactic sugar in your favourite programming language.
Instead, we'll use nil to denote an empty list and list val tail for a list node,
where tail is either another node, or nil.
So (list a (list b (list c nil))) f x evaluates to f a (f b (f c x))
and nil f x evaluates to just x.

content.title: The antediluvian map fragment
descr: Build function map f that applies a given function to each element of a list.
You can use list and nil to build the result, but aren't required to.
cases: map f (lst a nil) g y
map f (lst a(lst b (lst c nil))) g y

descr: Find the tail of a list, or an empty list if the list is empty.
